--- title: "Tucson Car Collision Analysis" subtitle: "INFO 526 - Fall 2023 - Project Final" author: - name: "**Data Dazzlers**:
Sanja Dmitrovic, Jiayue He, Vidhyananth Sivashanmugam,
Naitik Shah, Varun Soni, Mohammad Ali Farmani" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: images/watercolour_sys02_img34_teacup-ocean.jpg data-background-size: stretch data-background-opacity: "0.7" data-slide-number: none format: revealjs: theme: ['data/customtheming.scss'] output-file: project_final.html editor: visual execute: echo: false --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Introduction ::: incremental - The primary goal of the project is to develop a *user-friendly visualization tool* that provides detailed insights into the frequency, severity, and causes of traffic accidents in Tucson. - **GIS Data from the City of Tucson** - This data set contains publicly-available records of vehicle collisions from the Tucson Police Department, covering the period from March 2022 to the present. - Key variables in this data set are: - Date of collision - Injury severity - Manner of collision - Fatality status ::: ## Project Approach ::: incremental - Utilize R Shiny to create interactive dashboard, allowing users to filter and explore the data based on specific criteria (e.g., time period, accident severity). - Implement Leaflet for interactive maps to display spatial data and identify accident hotspots within Tucson using the latitude and longitude coordinates in the dataset. - Use ggplot2 and Plotly for creating dynamic and static visualizations that can be adjusted according to user input. ::: ## Question 1 ::: incremental ::: {.incremental width="40%"} - Does day of the week and/or time of day affect severity and the number of accidents? - Key variables to use: - TimeOccu (time at which accident occurred) - Day (day of week accident occurred) - InjurySeverity (how serious the injury caused by accident was) - Plot Approach: - Monthly time series of accidents ranging from 2018 to 2024. These years will be plotted as separate lines. - Heat map of accidents by hour and day of the week. ::: ::: ## Question 1 Results and Key Observations ### Monthly Time Series - Tucson experiences the most accidents in 2019 compared to any other year. 2020 sees the least amount of accidents. - Fewer accidents occur in summer months than winter months. ![](images/yearly_plot.PNG) ### Hourly Heat Map - Weekdays see higher frequencies of car accidents than weekends. - For weekdays (Monday - Friday), most accidents occur from 1pm to 6 pm. However, weekends do see an increase in accidents in the afternoon/evening as well. ![](images/question_1_part_2.PNG) ## Question 2 ::: incremental - What is the relationship between the type of violation and if the accident resulted in a fatality? - Key variables to use: - FatalCollision - TotalFatalities - Plot Approach: - Stacked bar plots that show the number of accidents based the type of violation. - Pie charts to provide a high-level summary of the percentage of crashes per violation type. ::: ## Question 2 Results and Key Observations ### Injury Severity (Stacked bar plots) - It is observed that 50.2% of accidents do not result in injury. - However, 49.8% of drivers do experience injury from car accidents in Tucson. The most common injury types are non-incapacitating injury and possible injury. - It is also seen that 1.6% of accidents with fatal injury. ![](images/injury_severity.png){fig-align="center"} ### Collision reason (Pie Chart) ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} - The most common location of collisions is at intersections (74.7%), showing that caution must be taken in these areas. - 38.1% of collisions involve a distracted driver and 18.5% involve a speeding driver. - For the future, it would be interesting to see how different collision reasons are correlated. For instance, do distracted drivers tend to speed? This could potentially help introduce stricter regulations on phone use, for example. ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](images/question_2_part_2.PNG){fig-align="right"} ::: ::: ## Thank You ![](images/thankyou.jpg){fig-align="center"}
